tagDescription: Richard Willing to Baring Bros. & Co. Re improvement in money and exchange-informs them that S. Jaudon has resigned his situation as Cashier of the Bank United States and that Joseph Copperthwait succeeds him - Rumours concerning Jaudon's further movements.
J.B. Perrault, Union Bank of Louisiana, New Orleans: Question of selling bonds for reimbursement.
Sam Comly: Expects a short wheat crop.

Memo of Contract for the sale and management of the Scrip of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts signed by Josiah Quincy Jr., Edmund Dwight, Thos. B. Wales, Committee of Finance for the Western Railroad corporation and T.W. Ward for Baring Bros. & Co.
Henry G. Chapman, Boston: Statement of account.
Unsigned: List of Louisiana Bond with dates of maturity.
Joshua Bates to A.L. Foresteza, Batavia: Partnership with Barings.
P. Perit to J. Bates - regarding the financial and commercial situation in both countries.
Rob. Trueman: Received advice against new business.
Samuel D. Bradford to J. Bates - Concerning the commercial and financial state of affairs. Refers to the Northern & Central Bank of Manchester
Sam Cabot: Building a new ship of 500 tons.
Herman LeRoy: Claims against the former House of LeRoy, Bayard & McEvers.
A.P. Hayne: Removal of prohibitions on foreign insurance companies.
A. Vail: Repayment of personal loan.
Archibald Gracie: Request for an agency of a London Fire Insurance Company.
T.W. Ward to Hon. Samuel Hubbard - State of the Banks throughout the country warrants the resumption of specie payments - Four objections to this are stated - then refuted.
Samuel Comly: Refers to closing the account.
Richard Willing: Information of R.&J. Philips loans. Messrs. Rotchild & Co. ceased to ship quicksilver to them.
S.&F. Dorr & Co.: Statement of assets and liabilities.
John A. Stevens: Reports ship Tiger clearing for Liverpool.
L. Harris: Request for credit for a friend.
Thos. M. Storrow: Expects repeal of law preventing agencies of foreign fire offices being established in New York. Asks for recommendation to suck office.
Circular of New York Committee to the Banks - Gallatin, Newbold, Lawrence.
R.C. Hooper: Business matters.
W. Nott & Co. to Thomas Baring - Re rumours affecting the credit of The Consolidated Association.
Unsigned: List of correspondents.
C.A. Davis: Speculation about the message of the President of the United States.
T.W. Ward (portion of unsigned letter) to J.A. Stevens: statement of business.
Baring Bros. & Co. London to T.A. Curtis, Governor, Bank of England - Enclosing quotations of the exchange between London and the East India Company's Presidency &c. Press Copy.
B. Gott: Complaints about falling-off in the trade with United States.
Robert Daglish: Relating to shipment of steel for the Georgia, Alabama and Florida Railway Co.
Sam D. Bradford, London: New partnership agreement with Henry S. Ballard and James McCall.
Thomas Wilson & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Re postponement of payment of notes given to the Bank of England, endorsed by them.
Filipe Biera, Paris: Business matters.
Samuel Comly to Baring Bros. & Co. With regard to Mr. Ward's instructions as to his account with them.
Assets & Liabilities of the 1st, 2nd and 3rd Municipalities of New Orleans.
Cummins Bros.: Account of cost of wheat.
Unsigned: List of business failures in New York.
Edward C. Delavan: Account of interviews with the King of France and the Duke of Orleans.
Wm. Sturgis Jr.: Introducing former partner Mr. Littlefield.
G.R. Russell: Remittance for Ceylon tea.
Joshua Bates to Messrs. Collings & W.? Respecting credit of 5,000 pounds.
Unsigned: Credit on Prime & Co.
E.J. Lawford: Enclosing letter from Laces, Clay and Myers relative to the claim of Sam Thompson & Son.
Count Joseph Survelliers: Enclosing letter to Mr. Biddle (missing).
Richard Willing to Baring Bros. & Co. His opinion re Bank of United States and the President's hostility towards it - The Prest's attitude towards France and the Treaty of Indemnity.
Joshua Bates to John Baring - Re Hottinguer's proposal to the Bank of England &c.
James H. Hale to J. Bates - Requesting his influence in favour of Mr. Joseph Francis, investor of the "Francis Patent Life Beats".
H. Lavergne to Baring Bros. & Co. Re affairs of the Consolidated Association.
H. Lavergne to Thomas Baring re affairs of The Consolidated Association of Planters of Louisiana.
Statement - Mortgagees of Inglis & Co.
F.W. Saltonstall: Request for credit.
John Hagan: Request for credit to pay bill.
George Stone: Offer of 50,000 pounds for the purpose suggested by Barings.
G.E.O. Wilder: Thanks for support and confidence.
A.L. Foresteer: Arrival of sugar. Shipment of other produce promised.
Statement of Deposits for Credits on Prime & Co.
A. Howard: Describes financial difficulties.
C.G. Allhusen: Establish of Factor house.
Henry G. Chapman: Business drafts and personal matters.
A.G. Jaudon: Requests for payment of a portion of commission.
Joshua Bates to Sidney Brooks: Request for credit.
Israel Whitney to Baring Bros. & Co. Enclosing copy of letter of 14 Feb. 1838 withy statement of the affairs of George Knight.
S.&F. Dorr & Co. to J. Bates - requesting the assistance of his House in operations with the Bank of England.
Edward Austin & John E. Lodge to Baring Bros. & Co. Enclosing statement of the Banks of New Orleans December 1837-1838 - Re resumption of specie payment by Banks in other Southern States.
Edward Brooks, Boston: Finance for son's studies.
H.R. Kendall to Baring Bros. & Co. Making proposals as to methods of carrying on the wool business, which he would like them to agree to in company with him.
P. Macaulay: Reports business "prostrate" in the United States.
Thos. Wilson & Co.: Acknowledge the endorsement of bank notes.
Unsigned fragment of letter to Messrs. Gerborne & Co., Caleutta.
Geo. McDuffie: Asks for information on South Carolina loan.
Sam Comly: Balancing the account.
C.A. Davis, New York: Financial and political affairs.

Robert Gilmor & Sons to Baring Bros. & Co. Introducing Judge Buchanan and General Emory, Commissioners who are about to visit Europe for the purpose of negotiating a Loan to enable the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. Chesapeake and Ohio Canal & Eastern Railroad Companies to complete their works
Augustus Thorndike to J. Bates. Making enquiries re Mr. Oelrichs (?) of Boston and Bremer.
M. Morgan, Union Bank of Louisiana: Instruction to continue sale of bonds.
William Hancock: Flaxseed.
John Parker to Baring Bros. & Co.: The Cotton market - Consolidated Association - Union Bank, Canal Bank &c.
A.G. Jaudon, Philadelphia: Cotton market; Extensive purchases of cotton.
Francis Baring: Political news from France and the resulting rise of insurance rates.
Wm. Sturgis Jr.: Business matters.
J.D.M - : American Stocks and Louisiana Bonds.
Thos. L. Harman: Sale of his father's property; personal.
Charles H. Todd to T.W. Ward: Settlement of outstanding account.
A. Vail, Paris: Personal loan of money.
G.R. Russell: Dispute with John Brown & Co. relative to sugar purchases at Manila on a credit from G. Wildes & Co.
Unsigned: Statement of the affairs of G. Wildes & Co.
Martin Gordon Jr. Cashier Union Bank, Louisiana, to Baring Bros. & Co. The affairs of the Union Bank of Louisiana.
Henry G. Chapman: Personal and views on slavery.
Gracie, Prince & Co.: Arrangement for commission on consignments.
F.F. Dorr: Heard that credit is given to parties which have accounts with other London Bankers.
E.&J. Lawford: Included legal opinion relating to the debt of Sam Comly.
Patterson & Magwood: Gives information on the Bank of the State of South Carolina.
Thomas Marcon to J. Bates - Introducing George Peabody of Baltimore.
Louis McLane - on Baltimore & Ohio Railroad affairs.
Sam. Stickney: Request investment in Virginia 6% stock.
Unsigned to Sam F. Gair: Improvement in business; continued operations in cotton.
Robert R. Hunter to J. Bates: Enclosing document clearing him of charges against him as American Consul at the Port of Cowes, with respect to extravagant charges in his capacity of Ships' Agent.
T.W. Ward to B.T. Reed: Terms of purchase of railway steel.
Wm. H. Robertson: Opportunities of investment in real estate.
P.A. Labouchere: Political affairs in the United States. Personal.
J.A. Stevens to T.W. Ward: The use of credit; cotton market
H.R. Kendall: Wool market.
Jos. M. White: Consignment of cotton in payment of debt.
H. Rogers Kendal to J. Bates. Enclosing correspondence with the Comptroller of the Treasury regarding free wools - &c.
Davis Brooks & Co. to T.W. Ward: Settlement of outstanding account.
A. Vail, Paris: Disappointed because was not appointed to an American consular office; personal.
Francis Baring: Political news from Spain.
M. Morgan, Union Bank of Louisiana, New Orleans: Enclosing copy of resolution adopted at the meeting of directors.
Henry G. Chapman: Business and personal matters. Also press copy of reply with directions as to personal drafts.
S. Jaudon to J. Bates - Reports numerous failures.
Horace Gray: Personal matter.
James Buchanan to J. Bates - Introducing Professor Flint of the Transylvania Medical College, Kentucky.
Abm. Bell & Co. to Goodhue & Co. Re flaxseed market. See also 10 March 1834, 31 December 1833.
Geo. Knight: Extract of letter about suspension of payments of Carrera & Co.
Character of the Hong Merchants.
A. Vail to Joshua Bates - Reference to the Canadian insurrection - The Political situation in United States &c.
R.M. Blatchford: Personal.
Papers relating to Delaware and Raritan Railroad and Camden and Amboy Railroad.
T.W. Ward to Messrs. Neal & Co. Encloses letters of credit (missing).
Edward Austin and John E. Lodge to T.W. Ward: Cotton market; low prices expected.
Veritas, New York: Financial ruins in New York.
H.R. Kendall: Wool market; high prices and strong demand.
R.C. Hooper to J. Bates stating reasons which compelled him to apply to the agent of Messrs. Morrison, Cryder & Co. - Criticizes Mr. T.W. Ward most unfavourably.
Gabriel Shaw: Scheme to enhance value of North American stocks.
Lord Ashburton: Admits his banking position as critical. Also undated portion of letter with views on banking and exchange operations.
John A. Stevens to J. Bates. Re commercial and financial affairs in the South.
G. Griswold: Detention of the vessel Nile at Canton.
Extract from a letter from Philadelphia in relation to the payment of dividends.
T.R. Putnam, Boston: Procures Vessel to ship 120 tons of sugar to Antwerp.
W. Nott & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Confidential information re Bank of Louisiana and The Canal and Banking Co.
D. Lynch: Referring to a letter of Herman LeRoy.
Unsigned: Bank list of firms.
Hunt Brothers: Introduction of steam navigation should speed up business. Also letter of 26 January, 1839.
Joseph, Count Survellers: Financial matters.
Walter Smith, Georgetown: Introducing Judge Buchanan in connection with a loan for Maryland.
Herman LeRoy to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing to them a Power of Attorney to act for them in case of his claim against the British Government.
Lovell Follett to Baring Bros. & Co. The Cotton market - Comments on banking concerns.
General statement of the Consolidated Association of the Planters of Louisiana.
Statement of Consolidated Association.
Francis Baring: American Treaty.
Sam Comly: Business failures.
Samuel Comly: Reports Thomas Oxnard & Son of Marseilles suspended payments. Also letter of 21 January 1837.
W. Channing Gibbs to Baring Bros. & Co. Complaint against T.W. Ward.
Geo. Griswold to J. Bates - Enquires whether their House will receive certain Bonds of the City of Orleans for sale.
H.R. Kendall to Baring Bros. & Co. Containing a description of wools suitable for the market.
Joshua Bates to J. Baring, Paris: Hottinguer's proposal; business failures.
Achille Wood (?) New Orleans: Personal.
H.R. Kendall: Wool market; demand for it and rising prices.
C.A. Davis to J. Bates - The political and financial prospects.
Unsigned, London: List of business firms with overdue accounts.
H.S. Mildmay: Addition of new articles of partnership.
Sam Comly: Sale of Flaxseed. Points out difficulties in resuming business after failure.
H. Lavergne, Cashier of The Consolidated Association, to Baring Bros. & Co. Affairs of the Association.
H. Lavergne to Baring Bros. & Co. Affairs of the Consolidated Association.
Abm. Bell to Goodhue & Co.: Flaxseed trade.
J.H. Shepherd, Union Bank, New Orleans: Wishes to close the accounts of the Nashville Railroad Co.
Davis & Brooks, New York: Reports pressure on money; political news.
Davis, Brooks & Co. and Horace Gray & Co., Boston to T.W. Ward: Business matters.
Contract re conveying mail from Rio de Janeiro to Para and back. Sgd/ Jose I. Borges - J.T. Thomas.
T.H. Perkins: Embarks on a trip to the Virginia Springs.
D. Lynch: Claims of LeRoy, Bayard and McEvery on the British Government.
Wm. H. Robertson, Liverpool: About draft of 5,000 pounds.
L. Harris: Requests to draw for 500 pounds.
A. Vail: Personal.

S.D. Bradford, Manchester to J. Bates- re rumours of a Bank to be established in New York under the auspices of Astor, Prime, Whitney, Bronson, Lenox & others- Also another under Mr. Biddle with a Capital of $10,000,000.
George Bond: Reference to Mr. Simpson who is about to embark for England.
Davis & Brooks: About application to import 3,000 tons of railroad steel.
Bird & Gillilan, New York: Refers to credit which was granted to him,
S.&F. Dorr & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Closes their account with them and states the financial standing of their firm.
Horace Binney (for the Girard Bank) to Baring Bros. & Co. Terms upon which he authorizes them to dispose of twenty thousand shares of the Bank.

C.G. Allhusen, New Orleans, to Baring Bros. & Co. Re the establishment of an extensive Factor house with European capital and connections &c- Enclosing extracts from the Treasury Department to the House of Representatives about the Increase of Cotton.
John Brown & Co. to G.R. Russell: Copies of correspondence relating to marketing of sugar.
Sam Comly: Copy of proceedings upon the failure of business.
Unsigned: List of firms with accounts.
Joshua Bates to T.W. Ward. Advising him as to policy to be followed with regard to Bank of United States. Comments upon the financial situation in United States. Press Copy.
Joseph Coolidge, Jr.: Request for additional credit.
F de Lizardi & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Re their communication in which they decline to pay over the balance in their hands due to the Mexican Government.
T.W. Ward to Sam Comly: Copies of letters about settlement of account.
John Brown, Paris: Discussed latest financial events.
B.F. Stockerton: Value of American stocks.
Unsigned to T.W. Ward: sugar market.
Stanton Parker, Jr., Boston: Copies of correspondence with T.W. Ward about coffee shipments.
Exports & Imports of the United States of America of the following articles of foreign growth in 1833-4-5 - Tea, Coffee, Sugar, Molasses &c.
M. Sussmann: Offer of services; discusses political situation. Refers to Napoleon's Berlin and Milan Decrees.
Sam Comly: Introducing John Brenchley who wished to purchase grain.
Sam Cabot: R.B. Forbes left for Canton and about other business matters.
W.G. Coesvelt to J. Bates concerning his Canada Stock - better trade conditions follow election.
H.R. Kendall, Boston to Geo. Wolf, Comptroller of the Treasury: Wool duties.
Thos. Henderson, Commercial Bank: Inquires about a loan of 200,000 pounds.
R.C. Hooper: Partnership agreement with T.C.W. Pierce and Edward Belknap.
S. Jaudon: Loan of money to Messrs. Gowan & Marx.
A. Welles: Advises that he is still in business and accepts letters of credit.
Martin Gordon, Jr., Cashier Union Bank Louisiana, to Baring Bros.& Co. Information of the amount issued by the State, the City and the three municipalities, by Bonds &c.
Sam Russell: Suggestion to ship goods to China before the expiration of the charter of the East India Company.
John Griswold: About establishing a line of Packets.
Unsigned to W.S. Stell, Manchester: Needs his signature to liquidate the estate of Thomas Wilson & Co.
J.B. Perrault, Union Bank of Louisiana, New Orleans: List of draft for collection.
Abraham Howard: Shipment of goods, remittances.
H. Schaeffer: Cotton market.

Relative to a contract in England for the importation into the United States of Iron Rails required for the Georgia, Alabama & Florida Railroad Co. N.B. This correspondence covers from April 1836 to March 1839.
Sam Comly to T.W. Ward: Reports progress in settlement of debts.
Jonathan Goodhue to J. Bates - Money market and Exchange. Refers to failure of Northern & Central Bank in Manchester.
E. Austin & J.E. Lodge to T.W. Ward: Reports demand for cotton.
William J. Young to T.W. Ward - Regrets to inform him that the Branch of the State Bank of Mobile has suspended specie Payments; detailing circumstances in connection with the event.
Lewis Rogers: Financial affairs.
Amount of Taxable property in each Country from 1826-1838.
E.S. Gannett: Remittance of balance of account.
Joseph, Count Survellers: Personal.
Geo. Knight & Co., Havana: Sugar and coffee market.
Estimate of American Stocks held abroad principally in England, given in Mr. Gartland's Speech in Congress against the sub-treasury Bill. Niles: Register.
A.P. Hayne to J. Bates - re present condition of England and United States in their commercial relations.
T. Wiggin & Co., London: Bank of England tightened credit.
A.F. Insinger to Thos. Baring. Stating their position with regard to the present commercial depression.
Edward Bury and George Forrester: Testify that railway steel returned from the United States was of adequate quality.
Robert R.Hunter, New York: Speculation in Real Estate.
Edward Tesser: Claims against Messrs. Hedge and Company.
Wm. Sullivan to Baring Bros. & Co. Explains his account with them. N.B. annexed is a note to J.Bates in which he discusses the political situation.
Russell Sturgis: Advises on manner of loading and maintenance of ships.
Cornelius Coolidge: Request to have the articles dispatched. Political news.
J.J. Dixwell: Business matters; high prices of cotton.
Jas. Wadsworth, Geneseo: Letter of credit for James S. Wadsworth.
Agreement between the American houses and T. Wiggins.
S.D. Bradford: Would engage moderately if money available. Financial prospects.

M. Morgan, President Union Bank of Louisiana to Baring Bros. & Co. Enclosing copy of circular addressed to several Bankers in London for the purpose of ascertaining the terms upon which they would be disposed to accept the agency.
J.A. Stevens to T.W. Ward: Purchases of cotton.
Lord Ashburton to Baring Bros. & Co. Expresses his opinion on the letter addressed to their house concerning the liquidation of the Debt of Mr. Katz to the firm.
Advices on markets - Coffee, Cochineal, Cotton, Pepper, Pimento, Indigo, Sugar &c. Sgd/ Samuel Byerley.

Copies of letters from the Mississippi Union Bank to Baring Bros. & Co. Liverpool - N.B. These copies cover the period 1 December 1838 - 8 February 1842 and are signed by H.G. Runnels, Pres., Wm. P. Grayson, Cashier, I.B. Morgan, Prest. in succession to H.G. Runnels, an C.W. Clifton, J. Elliot, Chas. Scott, Assignees of the Mississippi Union Bank.
Roswell L. Colt, New York: Sale of 2,000 shares of the United States Bank.
Leverett & Thomas: Policy on commercial bills.
H.S. Mildmay to Mr. Baring. Enclosing letter from Lord Ashburton with his opinion of the West India Bank scheme
Wm. Sturgis, Jr.: Proposes repayment of balance on account due Barings.
F.W. Saltonstall: asks advance of 50 pounds.
Union Bank of Louisiana: Transmission of securities.
J.J. Eschlan: Offer of services.
Lord Ashburton: Suggests to borrow 100,000 pounds in Exchequer Bills from the Bank of England.
Thomas Marcan: Informs that C.&M. Humphrey now able to pay old debts.
Joseph M. White to Hon. Francis Baring M.P. Re certain grants of Land in Louisiana made by the United States to General La Fayette to which Mr. Baring holds a title.
Jno. A. Stevens to J. Bates - The Cotton market.
List of New York and Boston failures.
Wm. Sturgis, Jr.: Foresees upturn in business.
Thomas Wilson & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Requesting their attendance at a meeting of the creditors to take into consideration the proper course to pursue in the present situation of affairs.
A.M. Robinson: Promises to settle account.
Ed. Ryan to J. Bates - Re the probability of his brother, Thomas Ryan, opening a business in Dublin in connection with the Quebec House.
J.F. Hellmers & Sons: Takes his sons into partnership.
Lord Ashburton: Comments on the annexation sentiment in the United States in respect to Texas.
Stanton Parker, Jr.: Shipment of coffee for c/c of Jas. H. Brewer.
C.A. Davis: Political news.
Abm. Bell & Co.: Flaxseed trade.
Geo. McDuffie: Departs for Italy; leaves instructions about the stock of the State of South Carolina.
Chas. Kerr: Corrects rumour that Barings not interested in American business.
S.D. Bradford to J. Bates - Re Jaudon's Mission - Affairs of Bank United States and financial matters generally.
David Sears: Loan to furnish dowry for daughter.
Baring Bros. & Co. to Nicholas Biddle - Explanatory of their business & standing in the markets of the world. (Press copy).
Semi-annual Dividends of the Girard Bank for two years. Sgd/ Wm. D. Lewis.
A.F. Insinger, Amsterdam: Reports little overtrading in Amsterdam.
Robert Gilmor: Relates to remittances on bills.
Louis McLane to J. Bates - Introducing Richard M. Blatchford, of New York, confidential agent of the Morris Canal and Banking Co., who visits London in the interests of that Company.
Gowan & Marx: Relating to four and a half millions Union Loan.
Wm. Peirce: Request for agency of shipping line.
List of New York failures.
An Act requiring the Banks of this Commonwealth (Pennsylvania) to make quarterly statements to the Auditor General and for other purposes.
Gowan & Marx: About a loan to the Union Canal. Also contemplation of loan to Virginia.
E. Stafford: Loan on the securities of the Philadelphia and Cuba.
Abstract of accounts of Robert C. Hooper, R.C. MacKay, Wm. Savage, Boston; Brothers Cramer, St. Petersburg; Hepburn Pillans & Co., Trieste.
Thos. B. Wales: Withdrawal from the firm of Thomas B. Wales & Co.
State of the Girard Bank. Sgd/ James Schott, President.
Henry Edwards & Co.: Refers to drafts on Porter, Danny & Co.
C.A. Davis: Expects fluctuations in money market to result in profitable operations.
P. Perit: Leaves for America to look for new opportunities.
Joshua Bates to Baring Bros. & Co. Account of his operations in Paris-meeting with Baron Rothschild.
Sam Comly to T.W. Ward: Copies of correspondence about losses on shipment of merchandise.
T.W. Ward to Messrs. Lodge and Austin, New Orleans: Shipments of cotton
Documents relating to An Act Supplementary to an Act entitled "An Act to incorporate the Gerard Bank in the City of Philadelphia passed on the third day of April 1832".
Talbot, Olyphant & Co.: Purchases of cotton. Trade with China.
List of overdue accounts and acceptances.
Gracie & Sargent to Baring Bros. & Co. Forwarding copy of a circular issued by John Ingersoll who signs himself Agent for Humphreys & Biddle re the Cotton market and its possible effect upon trade.
A Statement of the Responsibilities and Assets of the General Council of the City of New Orleans, previous to the division of the same into three separate municipalities.
State of the Bank of America, New York. Sgd/ D. Thompson, Cashier.
G.R. Russell: Balance on account.
Henry G. Chapman: Informs of drafts which he entered to the credit of B.B.
Davis & Brooks: Railroad steel.
P.A. Labouchere: Bates discourages entering indigo trade.

John Forsyth, Secretary of State, Washington, to Baring Bros. & Co. Notifies them that the business now being transacted by them on behalf of the United States is transferred to N.M. Rothschild at London.
Roswell L. Colt, New York: Request for extension on loan.
Thos. Wilson & Co.: Request extention of time on notes.
John T. Rowlandson, London: Memo of sundries adapted for a cargo from British America to the Mauritius market.
Alex Benson & Co., Thomas Biddle & Co., C. Macalester, Stock and Exchange Brokers of Philadelphia certify the cash prices of the Girard Bank Stock during the month of April.
E.J. Forstall et al, to Baring Bros. & Co. As Commissioners of the Citizens' Bank making enquiries re their charges in connection with their business.
T.B. to Baring Bros. & Co. Re cotton situation - Gair's fears about the Banks - King's estimates of his own and other Houses.
J.A. Stevens to T.W. Ward: Cotton account, also extract from letter of 8 April 1838; Copy of letter from Wm. Nott & Co. of 29 March 1838; and letter from Wotherspoon & Co. of 14 April 1838.
Joshua Bates, New York to Joshua Bates, London, requesting aid for Middlebury College, Vermont, with which he is connected.
Henry M. Labouchere: Refers to his visit to Boston. Expects more business failures in connection with the resumption of specie payment.
Unsigned memo suggesting sources of profit to the United States Banks by the difference in rate of Exchequer in England and commercial discounts in the United States.
C.A. Davis: Comments on President's message.
A Memorandum for the Investment of 10,000 pounds Sterling in wool. Signed H.R. Kendall.
N.L. & Geo. Griswold to Baring Bros. & Co. Objecting to rules laid down in their circular, with regard to Bills, and giving reasons therefor.
Wm. Sturgis, Jr.: Settlement of account.
